Facility and Regulated Substances:
Aurorium Zeeland facility is a specialty chemical company with on-site storage and usage of ethylene, a primary raw material in the manufacture of a co-polymer product. Ethylene is being used in the manufacture of an ethylene/maleic anhydride (EMA) co-polymer product that is used in the glass fiber industry. The ethylene is stored under pressure in two (2) transport tube trailers, each capable of holding approximately 14,000 pounds of ethylene. The ethylene is connected directly from the transport trailer to the manufacturing operation through a piping manifold located in the EMA facility.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program:
As part of the compliance effort with OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and Michigan's Department of Labor (R325.18302) regulations, the Zeeland facility has completed detailed reviews of critical plant operations in order to assess their inherent safety readiness. These programs are specifically aimed at minimizing and/or eliminating the consequences of catastrophic releases. This is done by stating the policies and procedures for the management of process hazards in design, construction, start-up, operation, inspection, maintenance, employee training, and emergency response.

Key to the success of these programs is the active involvement and participation of the employees in the completion of the process hazard analyses. The facilitys commitment to the use of the latest process hazard analysis techniques, detailed and accurate procedures and regular employee training, ensures that each critical safety component of ch

emical processing operations is reviewed in detail.

Five Year Accident History:
The facility had no accidental releases from the regulated process within the last five years that meet the five-year accident history criteria.

Emergency Response Program:
The overall emergency response program for the facility is coordinated with the local fire department and Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). Employees are trained to evacuate their respective areas in accordance with OSHA 1930.38(a). The facility has capability to communicate with appropriate organizations in the event of an emergency. This provides a means for notifying of an incident and facilitating quick response. 

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:
The facility plans to implement safety improvements driven by the most recent PHA and compliance audit. These changes include additional instrumentation, improvements in mechanical integrity procedures, revisions to the emergency response plan, and additional employee training.
